quoteFirst: On the other three nights when I’m not at the ball I stop at home, and get a bit of rest. Father sends us to bed early, about
quoteLast: , when I come home from school. On ball-nights I’m sometimes up to two o’clock in the morning.

quoteFirst: We returned to the middle of the town just as the shopkeepers in Friargate were beginning to take their shutters down. I had another engagement at
quoteLast: . A member of the Trinity Ward Relief Committee, who is master of the Catholic school in that ward, had offered to go with me to visit some distressed people who were under his care in that part of the town. We left Friargate at the appointed time.
title: Home-Life of the Lancashire Factory Folk during the Cotton Famine

quoteLast: and half-past ten. It was also in Italian. "All is lawful for the mother--advice and aid have started.

quoteFirst: Thus Voltaire sailed northward, noticed only by solitary policemen and lonely wayfarers. Near Eightieth Street his eye caught the burning circle of a clock pointing at
quoteLast: , and he stretched himself and yawned again. They were passing the vestibule of an old church which contrasted quaintly with the more ambitious modern architecture of the neighborhood. From the interior floated out the gray unison of a hymn.
title: Mortmain

quoteFirst: Mr. Ashley entered the manufactory that morning at his usual hour,
quoteLast: . He opened and read his letters, and then was engaged for some time with Samuel Lynn. By ten o'clock the counting-house was clear. Mr. Ashley was alone in it, and William knew that his time was come.

quoteTime: half past nine in the morn
quoteLast: ing, we left Addergey: hunger pressing us, we were prepared to do it earlier, and for this we had been up since five in the morning; but our loss of a mule obliged us, when we packed up our tent, to arrange our baggage differently.

quoteFirst: At Cyril Maxon's chambers in the Temple--very pleasant chambers they were, with a view over a broad sweep of the river--the day began in the usual fashion. At
quoteLast: Mr. Gibbons, the clerk, arrived; at a quarter to ten the diligent junior, who occupied the small room and devilled for the King's Counsel, made his punctual appearance. At ten, to the stroke of the clock, Maxon himself came in.
title: Mrs. Maxon Protests
